author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Resettling Letterings
description: Stephen McCarthy resolves to stump solvers with his second Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Stephen McCarthy is back, barely over two months since his Times debut, which was also a Sunday grid. That was the one about Canada, whence he hails; he is currently a Ph.D. student studying transportation modeling in Stockholm. Mr. McCarthy started his solving life working on cryptic crosswords for the Globe and Mail in Toronto with his grandfather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor, Arya Sundaram, Melena Ryzik and Cara Buckley
title: Turmoil Was Brewing at Time’s Up Long Before Cuomo
description: The prominent anti-harassment charity, criticized for its relationship with the former New York governor, is facing an identity crisis over its ties to those in power.
content: Nearly four years ago, moving with resolve after the global #MeToo explosion, some of the country’s most famous women formed a new charity, Time’s Up, to fight sexual harassment in the workplace. Their collective power, funds and aspirations offered the promise of real progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Go Around
description: Let’s tackle Joseph Greenbaum’s tricky New York Times debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really polished grid by a new constructor, Joseph Greenbaum, who has a few more puzzles already lined up. Almost all of the excellent long entries are debuts, and the fill that bubbles up in between them is fun and exuberant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharif Hassan, Dan Bilefsky and Max Fisher
title: A Taliban leader has arrived in Kabul, as the group aims to form a new government.
description: The leader, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, is beginning talks with former President Hamid Karzai and other politicians.
content: The Taliban appeared closer to forming a government nearly a week after seizing the capital as one of their leaders, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, arrived in Kabul to begin talks with former President Hamid Karzai and other politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Power companies warn that Henri could bring widespread outages.
description: Many utilities are bringing in extra help to try to minimize disruptions.
content: With powerful wind gusts, heavy rainfall and dangerous flooding soon expected to affect parts of the region as Hurricane Henri nears, officials across the New York metro area and New England are warning of possible widespread power outages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: A Starry Central Park Comeback Concert Is Silenced by Lightning
description: An all-star show to celebrate the city’s emergence after the hardships of the pandemic, even as the spread of the Delta variant has driven up cases again, was stopped halfway through.
content: It was supposed to be a glorious celebration of the re-emergence of New York City after more than a year of pandemic hardship — a concert bringing thousands of vaccinated fans on Saturday evening to the Great Lawn of Central Park to hear an all-star lineup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: Orlando residents are asked to cut back on water usage as the virus surges in Florida.
description: Hospitalizations are spiking and deaths in the Orlando area have overwhelmed crematoriums.
content: Orlando Mayor Buddy Dyer and utility officials asked residents to conserve water Friday to preserve the city’s supply of liquid oxygen, which is being used to treat a surging number of Covid-19 patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Jett
title: A Century After the Titanic Sank, a Film Tries to Rescue 6 Survivors’ Stories
description: “The Six,” a new documentary, attempts to track down the fate of Chinese sailors who survived the Titanic but were scattered by Western immigration laws.
content: Three days after the Titanic sank in April 1912, about 700 survivors shuffled into New York off another ship, the Carpathia, which had scooped them up from the icy North Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Citadel to Take Back $500 Million of Its Cash Infusion Into Melvin Capital
description: Melvin, a hedge fund that had bet that GameStop’s share price would fall, received a $2 billion infusion from Citadel after the stock skyrocketed.
content: The hedge fund Citadel pumped billions of dollars into Melvin Capital after that fund’s bet against GameStop went bad, leading to huge losses. Now, Citadel is taking some of its money back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Afghanistan Faces Economic Shock as Sanctions Replace Foreign Aid
description: The Taliban will be under pressure to keep a fragile economy afloat.
content: WASHINGTON — As the Taliban attempt the precarious shift from insurgent movement to functioning government, Afghanistan is facing the heightened risk of a financial collapse after being propped up for the past two decades by foreign aid that now accounts for nearly half its legal economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The situation at Kabul’s airport deteriorates as diplomats warn of threats.
description: Some Americans made it through the chaos at the airport despite warnings by the U.S. State Department to wait for orders to evacuate.
content: The State Department and Pentagon on Saturday gave conflicting messages to Americans seeking to flee Afghanistan through Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul, as security conditions continued to deteriorate at the remaining gateway out of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Tony Mendez, David Letterman’s Oddball ‘Cue Card Boy,’ Dies at 76
description: For more than 20 years, he wrote and flipped cards for Mr. Letterman’s “Late Show.” He was also a member of the show’s troupe of quirky onscreen characters.
content: Tony Mendez, who was in charge of cue cards for “Late Show With David Letterman,” as well as one of the show’s breakout oddball characters, until an altercation (over cue cards) with one of the writers got him fired in 2014, died on July 29 at his home in Miami Beach. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: The Congressional Black Caucus: Powerful, Diverse and Newly Complicated
description: The group, which includes most Black members of Congress, remains publicly united. But in private, an influx of new members who think differently about its purpose are making a play for the future.
content: The Congressional Black Caucus is the largest it has ever been, jumping to 57 members this year after a period of steady growth. The 50-year-old group, which includes most Black members of Congress and is entirely Democratic, is also more diverse, reflecting growing pockets of the Black electorate: millennials, progressives, suburban voters, those less tightly moored to the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Futterman and Talya Minsberg
title: Sha’Carri Richardson Finishes Last in Return to Track
description: Racing for the first time since a drug test kept her out of the Tokyo Olympics, Richardson and the rest of the field were no match for Elaine Thompson-Herah of Jamaica.
content: Sha’Carri Richardson sent a message before she returned to the track on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Health officials warn people not to treat Covid with a drug meant for livestock.
description: “You are not a horse,” the Food and Drug Administration said. “Stop it.”
content: Ivermectin, an anti-parasitic drug commonly used for livestock, should not be taken to treat or prevent Covid-19, the Food and Drug Administration said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: America’s Afghan War: A Defeat Foretold?
description: Recent history suggests that it is foolish for Western powers to fight wars in other people’s lands and that the U.S. intervention was almost certainly doomed from the start.
content: It was 8 a.m. and the sleepy Afghan sergeant stood at what he called the front line, one month before the city of Kunduz fell to the Taliban. An unspoken agreement protected both sides. There would be no shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: He Guarded Haiti’s Slain President. And He Was a Suspect in a Drug Inquiry.
description: Officials are examining whether President Jovenel Moïse’s killing was tied to the drug trade. The man in charge of his safety was a suspect in a major trafficking case, they say.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The commander in charge of guarding the Haitian president’s home quickly became a suspect in the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse last month when his security team inexplicably melted away, enabling hit men to enter the residence with little resistance and kill the president in his own bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: Can You Manifest Your Perfect Match?
description: Some relationship coaches believe healing from past traumas and dating with intention can help you find your person. But it may cost you over $10,000.
content: How much is too much to find the love of your life? $5,000? $10,000? $15,000?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Henri is barreling toward the Hamptons, ruining vacation plans.
description: Thousands across the upscale vacation destination were under evacuation warning during peak tourist season.
content: At the tip of a barrier island running along the southern shore of the Hamptons, restaurant staff piled outdoor tables and chairs into the basement on Saturday as sport fishing boats and yachts were being brought out of soon-to-be-surging water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michèle Montas
title: How to Escape the Cycle of Mismanaged Aid in Haiti
description: The unimaginable destruction I witnessed in the country demands that we do better now.
content: The 7.2 magnitude earthquake that struck Haiti a week ago has devastated the country, killing at least 2,189 people and upending the lives of about 1.5 million people west of the capital, Port-au-Prince. These people lack medical assistance, shelter, running water and food. To compound this catastrophe, they’ve had to deal with flooding and mudslides brought on by Tropical Storm Grace and gang violence threatening the convoys carrying equipment and supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Apoorva Mandavilli, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Erica L. Green, Emily Anthes and Noah Weiland
title: A guide to vaccine boosters.
description: Here’s what we know about booster shots — why Americans may need them and when they should get them.
content: This week, the Biden administration strongly recommended booster shots for most vaccinated Americans, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also released three studies that federal officials said provided evidence that booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna coronavirus vaccines would be needed in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: How to prepare before, during and after a hurricane.
description: Long Island and southern New England are preparing for the arrival of Hurricane Henri this weekend.
content: Hurricane Henri strengthened on Saturday and was expected to make landfall on Long Island or southern New England on Sunday, bringing heavy rain, potential flooding and a dangerous storm surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Videos show injuries, desperation as Afghans rush to enter Kabul airport.
description: The video clips suggest that almost a week after the Taliban seized Kabul, conditions near the airport are not improving and may be worsening.
content: Videos from Kabul airport on Saturday showed scores of injuries and adults passed out as Afghans clamored to be evacuated from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glynnis MacNicol
title: A Steamy French Thriller Is a ‘Sleeper Smash Hit’
description: The 1969 film “La Piscine” was supposed to run for two weeks at New York’s Film Forum, but it’s been extended to the fall.
content: For the past 14 weeks at Film Forum, a longstanding independent and repertory theater on West Houston Street in Manhattan, the 1969 French film “La Piscine” has been playing — a run that has extended its initial engagement by 12 weeks, and counting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: R. Kelly Trial: Key Moments From Week 1
description: The first days of the disgraced R&B superstar’s federal trial in Brooklyn included harrowing testimony from an accuser and details of his brief marriage to Aaliyah.
content: For decades, allegations of sexual misconduct have followed R. Kelly. But not until Wednesday, on the first day of his long-awaited criminal trial, did one of his accusers take the witness stand to testify against the disgraced R&B superstar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: California’s Gig Worker Law Is Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
description: Last year, more than $200 million was spent on campaigning for a state proposition that ensured workers like Uber and Lyft drivers were considered independent contractors.
content: A California law that ensures many gig workers are considered independent contractors, while affording them some limited benefits, is unconstitutional and unenforceable, a California Superior Court judge ruled Friday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Ran on Competence and Empathy. Afghanistan Is Testing That.
description: The chaotic endgame of the American withdrawal has undercut some of the most fundamental premises of President Biden’s presidency.
content: For most of the last week, in the fires of the worst foreign policy crisis of his young administration, the president who won the White House on a promise of competence and compassion has had trouble demonstrating much of either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: As Democrats Renew Voting Rights Push, Offsetting Roberts Court Is Top of Mind
description: The House’s voting rights legislation named for the civil rights leader John Lewis seeks to counter the Supreme Court’s longstanding bid to undermine the Voting Rights Act.
content: When Judge John G. Roberts Jr. faced the Senate for his Supreme Court confirmation hearing in September 2005, critics sounded the alarm about his longstanding skepticism toward the 1965 Voting Rights Act, which many view as crucial to the political gains of Black Americans over the last half century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Bill Freehan, Champion Tigers’ Durable Centerpiece, Dies at 79
description: An 11-time All-Star catcher, he played a key role in Detroit’s 1968 World Series victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
content: Bill Freehan, the 11-time All-Star catcher who guided the Detroit Tigers’ brilliant pitching duo of Mickey Lolich and Denny McLain as the Tigers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals for the 1968 World Series championship, died on Thursday at his home in the village of Walloon Lake in northern Michigan. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Athens Is Only Getting Hotter. Its New ‘Chief Heat Officer’ Hopes to Cool It Down.
description: Eleni Myrivili has been tasked with finding ways to help the Greek capital cope with ever-hotter heat waves that are expected to be part of life for years to come.
content: ATHENS — On the hottest day of Greece’s record-breaking heat wave, when temperatures in Athens rose to 111 degrees Fahrenheit and wildfires choked the air, Eleni Myrivili stopped hanging laundry on her rooftop behind the Acropolis because she could hardly breathe from the heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Marvar
title: Last Stop on the Way to the Cosmos? No Thanks.
description: A small Southern county hopes to land a starring role in the commercial space race. But for residents of the exclusive islands in the flight path, the stakes feel sky-high.
content: On an isolated archipelago off the coast of Georgia, where the vestiges of America’s Gilded Age aristocracy keep sprawling estates in tropical wilds, a controversy is roiling over a proposed spaceport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: A former Pence aide says Trump and Miller tried to stymie Afghan refugee efforts.
description: Olivia Troye said the Trump aide Stephen Miller demanded restrictions on refugees. Mr. Miller said President Biden’s “incompetence” had led to the current chaos.
content: A homeland security adviser to former Vice President Mike Pence accused the Trump administration of distorting the truth about Afghan refugees, writing on Twitter that the former president and Stephen Miller, his top immigration adviser, sought to prevent the refugees from entering the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Tom T. Hall, Country Music’s ‘Storyteller,’ Is Dead at 85
description: Mr. Hall, who wrote hits like “Harper Valley P.T.A.,” helped to imbue country lyrics with newfound depth and insight in the 1960s and ’70s.
content: Tom T. Hall, a country singer and songwriter known for wry, socially conscious hit songs like “Harper Valley P.T.A.,” died on Friday at his home in Franklin, Tenn. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Benefit Cutoffs Failing to Ease Labor Shortfall
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 21, 2021.
content: “It’s playing a role, but it’s not this on-off switch, where if you turn it off everyone goes back to work.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gerd Müller, Soccer Star Known for His Scoring Prowess, Dies at 75
description: He scored 566 goals for Bayern Munich, helping the club to four German titles, four German Cup wins and three European Cup victories in 15 years.
content: Gerd Müller, the German soccer scar who became known as “Der Bomber” for his scoring prowess, died on Aug. 15 in Wolfratshausen, Germany. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Ellen Barry
title: Long Island and New England Prepare for Rare Hurricane Strike
description: As Hurricane Henri approached the region, New York City prepared to shut down city beaches, and Boston erected flood barriers around its most vulnerable subway station.
content: As Hurricane Henri churned up the East Coast on Saturday, communities from New York City to Boston prepared for what would be the first hurricane to make landfall on Long Island or in New England in at least 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. seeks to compel airlines to provide planes to speed evacuation of Afghans.
description: Military officials are poised to activate the Civil Reserve Air Fleet. The defense secretary must still approve the decision, which would provide 20 planes to evacuation efforts.
content: The Pentagon is moving toward compelling major American airlines to help transport tens of thousands of evacuees from Afghanistan, as the military struggles to meet the demand from Afghans seeking to leave Kabul, the capital, after the Taliban took control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: In Iowa, Gaetz and Greene Pick Up Where Trump Left Off
description: At a rally in Des Moines, Representatives Marjorie Taylor Greene and Matt Gaetz showed that many Republicans do not plan to move on from the Trump era.
content: DES MOINES — Far from Washington, and even farther from their home congressional districts, Representatives Matt Gaetz of Florida and Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia found their people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: 50 Years After Vietnam, Thousands Flee Another Lost American War
description: The United States admitted more than 300,000 Southeast Asians after the Vietnam War. Analysts say there is little chance the country will repeat the extensive refugee resettlement effort.
content: It was the end of a decades-long American military engagement overseas, and thousands of U.S. allies were clamoring to board the last planes leaving for, they hoped, eventual resettlement in the United States. Their capital had fallen. Deadly reprisals for those who stayed behind were almost certain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Vietnam War Victims Wanted Justice. They Were Given ‘30 Bags of Rice.’
description: South Korean troops were the largest foreign contingent fighting alongside American soldiers during the Vietnam War. They have long been dogged by allegations of brutality.
content: SEOUL — The South Korean marine unit had a reputation for leaving nothing breathing behind when they passed through hostile territory, not even a pig suckling its litter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Reinstatements
description: Take a road trip through America with this John Suarez invention.
content: REINSTATEMENTS — Every August we get an out-of-the-ordinary variety puzzle from the National Puzzlers’ League Convention, which most recently took place in Washington, D.C., last month. This is the 181st Convention, impressively enough (they don’t go back to 1840, but the League formed in 1883 and the conventions have been held for a very long time). The program is similarly imposing, stuffed with quizzes and contests, including the word-pairing challenge we have today. I think this is a fun one, not too esoteric, although I wouldn’t want to have to speed-solve it competitively because a few stumpers had me mulling for quite a bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The School Kids Are Not Alright
description: A year of lost schooling will hurt children for years to come.
content: One of the most distressing aspects of the Covid pandemic has been seeing governors and state education officials abdicate responsibility for managing the worst disruption of public schooling in modern history and leaving the heavy lifting to the localities. Virtually every school in the nation closed in March 2020, replacing face-to-face schooling with thrown-together online education or programs that used a disruptive scheduling process to combine the two. Only a small portion of the student body returned to fully opened schools the following fall. The resulting learning setbacks range from grave for all groups of students to catastrophic for poor children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: We Weren’t Happy Before the Pandemic, Either
description: Covid-19 has forced us to take a close look at our lives. Many of us don't like what we see.
content: I do not remember the last conversation I had with my father before he died. The weeks and months before his passing were like the months and years of our life together: full of starts and stops. We tried to create the relationship we knew that fathers and sons should have but that we didn’t, because he left our family when I was young. There were times when I called and he did not answer. In other cases, I missed his attempts to connect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino
title: Desperation as Afghans Seek to Flee a Country Retaken by the Taliban
description: A surging crowd trampled a toddler to death near the airport, and many residents who aided America remain in hiding, fearing they will be killed by their new rulers.
content: On Saturday morning, a former interpreter for an American company in Kabul plunged into a mass of humanity outside a gate at the Kabul airport with her family in tow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: Resistance fighters drive Taliban from 3 districts in the mountains north of Kabul.
description: The Taliban faced the first armed challenge from former Afghan soldiers and villagers in the mountains north of Kabul.
content: The Taliban faced the first armed challenge to their rule as former Afghan soldiers, aided by villagers, drove the militants out of three districts in the mountains north of Kabul, according to former Afghan officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: So Your Rent Is About to Spike. Can You Avoid Paying More?
description: Renters are reeling with sticker shock as they discover just how aggressively New York’s housing market is bouncing back.
content: Q: My roommate and I moved to an East Village two-bedroom apartment in September 2020, paying $2,400 a month. Management recently informed us that our rent will go up to $3,600 a month when our market-rate lease comes up for renewal. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Colleen Cronin
title: ‘We’re New Englanders, we can handle it’: Storm prep is a mixed bag.
description: Residents were skeptical that Henri would be as damaging as Hurricanes Gloria and Bob, which struck the region in 1985 and 1991.
content: BOSTON — When it looked like Hurricane Henri would directly hit New England, customers converged on Adler’s Design Center & Hardware in Providence, R.I., where they bought all of the store’s kerosene lamps before moving on to flashlights and candles, said Leanne Dolloff, a cashier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: SPACs Went Up, Then Down, but They’re Not Out
description: New regulatory scrutiny and high-profile blowups have revived longstanding concerns about the public shell companies. But many backers seem undaunted.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino
title: Fears Rise About Safety of Afghan Airport as U.S. Warns Americans to Stay Away
description: Families continued to swarm the airport in hopes of getting aboard American military planes. U.S. officials are now worried that Islamic State might launch an attack to damage the Taliban’s sense of control.
content: Panic and desperation rose Saturday among thousands of Afghans struggling to flee the week-old Taliban takeover of Afghanistan, as gates to the Kabul airport were closed off and the U.S. embassy warned American citizens to stay away from the airport, citing “potential security threats outside the gates.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A Dollar Per Doughnut Per Day: One Man’s Vaccination Quest
description: Fueled by free doughnuts, Joe Caramagna is on a mission to encourage vaccinations, raise money for charity and satisfy his sweet tooth all at the same time.
content: Joe Caramagna, a man who searches “doughnuts near me” when he travels, had never lived a short walk from a doughnut shop. This was a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Taking the Pulse of the Ocean’s Comb Jellies
description: New kinds of molecular probes are revealing the true extent of ctenophores, a form of ocean life that has long eluded firm reckonings.
content: The enormousness of the global sea has, over ages of exploration, made the appraisals of prime inhabitants more like rough sketches than detailed portraits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: The Little League World Series Is the Pinnacle for the Umpires, Too
description: The players dream of nationally televised glory. But for the nervous and excited volunteer umpires, the goal is to go unnoticed.
content: Every game at the Little League World Series starts the same way — nine players on the field, another holding a bat, and an umpire behind the plate, as anxious as anyone else, pointing toward the mound and shouting, “Play ball!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Barbara Kannapell, Activist Who Empowered Deaf People, Dies at 83
description: She gave them a sense of identity and culture and helped legitimize American Sign Language, which she considered her native language.
content: Barbara Kannapell, a world-renowned deaf activist who made it her life’s work to empower deaf and hard-of-hearing people with a sense of identity and an appreciation for their own distinct culture, and who advanced the idea that American Sign Language was a legitimate, foundational language, died on Aug. 11 in Washington. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Gary B. Nash, 88, Dies; Drew Ire for Trying to Update History Education
description: A respected scholar of early America, he became a central figure in the culture wars that enveloped the country in the 1990s.
content: Gary B. Nash, a historian who became a reluctant national celebrity in the mid-1990s when his work on a set of national history standards made him a target for Rush Limbaugh, Lynne Cheney and other prominent conservatives, died on July 29 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Storm surge from hurricanes can threaten lives and damage property.
description: Henri, which strengthened into a hurricane on Saturday, was expected to create dangerous storm surges in Long Island and New England.
content: Hurricanes are defined by their powerful winds. But the storm surges they produce can often prove just as destructive in coastal communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Stanley Aronowitz, Labor Scholar and Activist, Dies at 88
description: As a self-described “working-class intellectual,” he declared that direct action was more potent than collective bargaining or conventional politics.
content: Stanley Aronowitz, a blue-collar organizer, university professor and prolific author who argued that electoral politics had failed American labor and that unions needed to adopt militant strategies to pursue a broad social agenda, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sobel
title: The approaching storm brings the risk of inland flooding.
description: Forecasters say the storm could stall over the mountains of the Northeast, causing flooding similar to Hurricane Irene in 2011.
content: Adam Sobel is a professor and director of the Initiative on Extreme Weather and Climate at Columbia University. He is an atmospheric scientist and host of the “Deep Convection” podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan C. Crocker
title: Why Biden’s Lack of Strategic Patience Led to Disaster
description: The American disaster in Afghanistan that Biden’s impatience brought about is not a disaster just for us. It's a huge boost for the Taliban too.
content: As Americans, we have many strengths, but strategic patience is not among them. We have been able to summon it at critical times such as the Revolutionary War and World War II, where, for example, Congress did not threaten to defund the war effort if it wasn’t wrapped up by 1944. In Korea, nearly seven decades after an inconclusive truce, we still have about 28,000 troops. But our patience is not the norm. And it certainly has not been on display in Afghanistan as the world watched the Taliban storm into Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: On Freddy Krueger and Our Current Nightmare
description: There’s a surprisingly relevant theme in the “Nightmare on Elm Street” series.
content: This is a preview of Jamelle Bouie’s newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox weekly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: In Melbourne, Australia, a protest against Covid restrictions turned violent.
description: The police said it was the first time officers had been forced to use “a range of nonlethal options” to disperse anti-lockdown protesters in Melbourne.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Protesters in Melbourne demonstrating against Covid restrictions on Saturday clashed with the police, who used pepper spray to disperse them. Several officers were injured and hundreds of people were arrested, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami
title: The Struggle to Save a House of Music, and Its Legacy
description: For decades, the Tangier home of Abdellah El Gourd has been a wellspring of the Gnawa musical tradition and a place of pilgrimage for jazz performers. But it has fallen into deep disrepair.
content: TANGIER, Morocco — For more than a half-century, a Moorish-style house in the old city of Tangier considered one of Morocco’s cultural gems drew musicians and other artists from around the world seeking to learn about the Sufi music and rituals of the descendants of slaves in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: ‘Nursing Is in Crisis’: Staff Shortages Put Patients at Risk
description: “When hospitals are understaffed, people die,” one expert warned as the U.S. health systems reach a breaking point in the face of the Delta variant.
content: Cyndy O’Brien, an emergency room nurse at Ocean Springs Hospital on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi, could not believe her eyes as she arrived for work. There were people sprawled out in their cars gasping for air as three ambulances with gravely ill patients idled in the parking lot. Just inside the front doors, a crush of anxious people jostled to get the attention of an overwhelmed triage nurse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Why Your Next Trip Might Be More Expensive Than Your Last
description: The cost of travel climbed this summer, but the Delta variant is weighing on demand. We looked into travel’s murky crystal ball to find out how prices will fare in the future.
content: Earlier this summer, travel’s comeback, especially strong in domestic leisure locations, meant travelers often paid more for flights, resorts and rental cars. But the wave of coronavirus infections linked to the Delta variant has somewhat clouded predictions about costs remaining high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: With evacuations on Fire Island, Long Island braces for Hurricane Henri.
description: Ferry service to the island will be suspended on Saturday night, and flights and rail service in the region will likely be affected.
content: With Hurricane Henri fast approaching on Saturday afternoon, Suffolk County officials called on visitors and residents of Fire Island, which lies on the southern shore of Long Island, to voluntarily evacuate before landfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Stockton and Lucy King
title: Dying in the Name of Vaccine Freedom
description: In Arkansas, many are choosing personal liberty over vaccination — at a heavy cost.
content: In the video above, Alexander Stockton, a producer on the Opinion Video team, explores one of the main reasons the number of Covid cases is soaring once again in the United States: vaccine hesitancy and refusal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: A Rough Beast Returns
description: We needed to leave Afghanistan. But not this way.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Biden watched Kabul descend into hell, did he think of his beloved Yeats?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Donors Send Quake Aid to Haiti, but for How Long?
description: Misuse of previous aid money, Haiti’s political convulsions, and competing humanitarian demands may signal less generosity this time.
content: The urgent pleas for donations to help Haiti cope with last Saturday’s magnitude 7.2 quake began almost immediately: Charities reported an initial outpouring of generosity for a poor country that has long depended on philanthropic aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger, Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Lara Jakes
title: Miscue After Miscue, U.S. Exit Plan Unravels
description: President Biden promised an orderly withdrawal. That pledge, compounded by missed signals and miscalculations, proved impossible.
content: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top national security officials assembled at the Pentagon early on April 24 for a secret meeting to plan the final withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan. It was two weeks after President Biden had announced the exit over the objection of his generals, but now they were carrying out his orders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: The British government is starting an antibody surveillance program.
description: The program, which is expected to begin on Tuesday, will allow for up to 8,000 participants each day who book a P.C.R. test through the National Health Service’s “test and trace” program.
content: The British government is starting an antibody surveillance program for adults who test positive for the coronavirus in order to develop a better understanding of its vaccine campaign and the immune response to different virus variants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Gebeloff, Denise Lu and Miriam Jordan
title: Inside the Diverse and Growing Asian Population in the U.S.
description: A Times analysis shows just how complex and nuanced the nation’s Asian population is — in geography, income, citizenship status and political preference.
content: A Times analysis shows just how complex and nuanced the nation’s Asian population is — in geography, income, citizenship status and political preference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meg Felling, Lucas Lilieholm and Dahlia Kozlowsky
title: 20 Years, 4 Presidents: The Words That Shaped the War in Afghanistan
description: From the invasion in 2001 to the sudden collapse of the Afghan government, we look back at two decades of shifting strategy in America’s longest war.
content: From the invasion in 2001 to the sudden collapse of the Afghan government, we look back at two decades of shifting strategy in America’s longest war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Evacuees From Afghanistan Arrive in Countries Abroad
description: Following the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan, dozens of countries have been working to evacuate their citizens and vulnerable Afghans, including those who have worked for the U.S. military or embassy.
content: Following the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan, dozens of countries have been working to evacuate their citizens and vulnerable Afghans, including those who have worked for the U.S. military or embassy.

title: Raising Boys Who Have Empathy and Emotion
description: “I can’t think of a more masculine, tough challenge than empowering boys to understand the emotional workings of themselves and others,” one reader writes.
content: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: Aug. 21, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 21, 2021.
content: An article on Page 4 this weekend about the project Theater in Quarantine by Joshua William Gelb, using information provided by a publicist, misstates the composer Heather Christian’s age. She is 39, not 29.
source.name: The New York Times
